titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Elizabeth Fink Papers, 1971-2015 RL.11343
titlestmt.author: Meghan Lyon

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-01-08 20:14:30 UTC.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Elizabeth Fink was a human rights lawyer who represented prisoners killed and injured during the 1971 Attica prison uprising. The collection consists of photographs gathered as evidence used in the subsequent lawsuits on behalf of Attica prisoners, represented by Fink, as well as some copies of trial transcripts and audiovisual recordings of news coverage, interviews, and footage.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by format: Photographs, Audiovisual Materials, and Papers; Papers largely consist of trial transcripts, printed materials, and clippings files about Attica.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Elizabeth Fink (1945-2015) was a human rights lawyer and activist who represented prisoners killed and injured during the 1971 Attica prison uprising.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Elizabeth Fink Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2016 with a subsequent gift in 2017.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Elizabeth Fink Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Ben Saalfeld and Meghan Lyon, November 2016. Updated by Laurin Penland, March 2017; Meghan Lyon, June 2017; Christian Cleaveland, Dec. 2017; Matthew Farrell, Jan. 2018.
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2016-0288, 2016-0328, 2017-0017, 2017-0027, 2017-0074, 2017-0197

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional materials documenting the Attica prison revolt can be found in the Jomo Joka Omowale Papers, also held in Rubenstein Library's Human Rights Archive.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of photographs gathered as evidence used in the subsequent lawsuits on behalf of Attica prisoners, represented by Fink, as well as some copies of trial transcripts and audiovisual recordings of news coverage, interviews, and footage of Attica Correctional Facility following the Attica uprising. There are also materials collected by Fink from the Attica Brothers Legal Defense. Content includes photographs and moving images of the prison uprising; guards and officials during the standoff; the subsequent assault and retaking of the prison ("Bloody Monday") by the Russell Oswald and the NY State Police; the aftermath of the assault, including images of the re-captured prisoners, deceased prisoners, debris from the uprising, and armed guards; morgue images and fingerprints of deceased inmates and hostages; interviews and news programs about the event; images of Attica prison facilities; and images and audiovisual of Fink's memorial service and the scattering of Fink's cremated remains. Some of the images and audiovisual materials have been digitized. Images depict graphic violence, nudity, and deceased persons. Collection acquired as part of the Archive of Human Rights (Duke University).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Contact Research Services in advance to request the production of listening or viewing copies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed materials about the Attica uprising and subsequent lawsuits and coverage, as well as Black Power and other items produced by the Attica Brothers Legal Defense Fund to advocate for prison reform, justice for Attica Brothers and other inmates, and civil rights. Also includes clippings about Fink and the work of the Attica Brothers Legal Defense.

"Fighting Back! Attica Memorial Book" (published by the Attica Brothers Legal Defense)

Attica Speakers Bureau pamphlet, listing available speakers; from the Attica Brothers Legal Defense / Attica Brothers Offense Defense
"Attica Chronology of Events 1971-1974" (published by the Attica Brothers Legal Defense)
"Attica: Then and Now, Still Fighting Back" (published by the Attica Committee to Free Dacajeweiah)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dates removed; only images from the calendar remain. Images of Attica, guards, other prisons.

did.unittitle: Newspaper photocopied clippings: aftermath and autopsies of the deceased
"Attica: The Hostages' Story," New York Times photocopied clipping
"Attica is all of us," National Lawyers Guild Spring Fling
"Remembering Attica" manuscript draft, with edits, by E. Fink, M. Deutsch, and Dennis Cunningham
"Remembering Attica," in the New York City News of the National Lawyers Guild

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a portion of the trial transcripts and Fink's plaintiff brief produced on behalf of Attica prisoners as part of their lawsuit over civil rights violations during the retaking of the prison.

did.unittitle: Al-Jundi vs. Oswald, etc. trial transcript
Al-Jundi vs. Rockefeller, etc. trial transcripts
Plaintiff brief for the liability appeal vs. C. Pfiel, U.S. Court of Appeals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs and color photocopies of prints documenting the Attica uprising, police assault, and aftermath, as well as files containing photographic evidence for some of the inmate and hostage deaths following the retaking of the prison on Sept. 13 1971. Files for hostages and deceased Attica Brothers (inmates) typically include images of the dead men following the assault, morgue photographs, and occasionally fingerprints or mugshots. There are also images of Attica's facilities collected as part of an evidence-gathering exercise in 1974. A number of the prints and smaller number of negatives were digitized by a third party.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room. To request access, please contact Research Services before coming to use these records.

did.unittitle: Brothers and hostages on catwalks, pre-assault

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unsorted, unlabelled slides that appear to relate to protests, evidence, and trials of the Attica Brothers. No additional context was included so slides have simply been rehoused for preservation with no further arrangement.

did.unittitle: Brothers on the ground in D-Yard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One folder contains color photocopies of prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Evidence-gathering materials including photocopied floorplans of the prison.

did.physdesc: Approximately 3000 digital images (JPEG and TIFF format); 225 gigabytes.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original VHS and audio-cassette labels have been retained. A number of the VHS cassettes have been digitized by a third party.

accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room. To request access, please contact Research Services before coming to use these records.
